content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Tony Hawk Pro Skater HD is a blast from the past. I can remember putting in countless  hours of play in this game with my friends. The original version was released on consoles when the Playstion one was new and hot. This game opened the door for skater games to be popular but no one did it as good as Pro Skater 1 & 2. Some of the newer Tony Hawk stuff is crap and are usually rated pretty bad but this isnt one of the bad ones. In my opinion this is the best Pro Skater game and the HD upgrade makes this an easy purchase. Everything about this game is the same as the original except the HD overhaul and change in soundtrack. As good as the game is theres not much new brought to the table. The mechanics are the same as I remember on PS1. I see alot of negative reviews for this but I think its because people remember the controls being more responsive than they were. I played the PS1 version recently and I couldn't wait to go back and play this version instead. The game is worth the $9.99 price tag, but if you are on the fence about it wait for it to go on sale again.7\10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Let me start by saying that what you pay is what you get. If you're willing to pay a few bucks for a small revisit, I'd recommend it. You can choose between a few levels from THPS and THPS2, all revamped in gorgeous HD graphics. The models and levels look fantastic. Skating around can be fun if you get around the bad physics.However, the game does have its flaws. The physics are wonky and sometimes irritating. The falling animation is just ridiculous. Also, this game lacks any customization at all. You can't change the controls, you can't change the looks of your skater, you can't create your own park, nothing. There isn't even a multiplayer modus. The only thing there is, is singleplayer. But, that didn't prevent me from having some fun while beating all the game's objectives.I myself have enjoyed many hours of singleplayer skating just because I liked the revamped levels and I got used to the wonky physics. Yes, there isn't a lot to this game, but this game is not a bad game for what you pay. It's just not a "full" Tony Hawk game, only a small revisit for a few bucks.I'd recommend this game despite its flaws, but only if you're a dedicated fan of this series. If you're looking for a "full" Tony Hawk's game, I heard he's working on a new title for this year.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Judged too harshly by both the media and gamers at large, THPS HD is far from a bad game. It's nowhere near as good as the main Tony Hawk games from years past, but it gets close at times and has very few real issues. The physics can be a little bit broken, and sometimes it has frustrating collision detection, but if you pick this up on a sale you'll have a few hours of nostalgia-fueled fun. With measured expectations, THPS HD comes recommended and gets a 6/10.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Controls and performs incredibly roughly. With levels and engine essentially lifted from the original games, you'd think that Robomodo could have at least gotten the physics to be half decent, but that's just asking too much of the developers of Ride and Shred. Random ramps and walls have awkward hitboxes that cause your skater to jet off in random directions.And the game doesn't even look good enough to justify the performance issues.Also, reverts locked behind paid DLC. REVERTS. The novelty was supposed to be in the levels, skaters, and feel, not in limiting the features. Speaking of limiting features, no real muliplayer to speak of. There's also a goal in the DLC that requires many of the characters to purchase a grab trick to put into their trickset, because it's not included in the standard street moveset. Remember how THPS3 had a ton of those kinds of goals, but Neversoft (RIP) were decent enough to actually only give goals for tricks that your skater already had. And even if you DO buy the trick and put it in the trickset for your skater, there's no guarantee that it will actually allow your skater to do the trick.Basically, this game is maybe worth it at 75% off. And only if you no longer have the system(s) you played the original games on, and don't want to emulate. And even then, only buy this game if you hate yourself.Then it might be worth it.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Game is great. It's reliving your childhood, but in HD. Graphics are great. The grinding and manual system is more or less the same, if not better. There are several character additions, although they did remove a few as well, which disappointed me, like Andrew Reynolds. You can also be James Hetfield of Metallica. You play, earn money, collect it in levels, go to the shop, and buy either boards, stats, or tricks. There's also a special cheat area where unknown objectives in the game will unlock a cheat/mod that you can enable in the game, such as unlimited grind, or just turn your player transparant using the "Ghost Mode." As well as cheats, you can also unlock side-games that come when accomplishing other unknown objectives. If you have a cheat enabled, the game does not award you achievements when you accomplish something, so you need to keep them off unless you feel like randomly free skating for fun.The turning accuracy of the player has definitely improved, whereas the original would sometimes give problems, causing you to slam into things. It just wasn't as sharp.Board customization is gone, but you can change your board still, not that it means anything.The saddest thing in this is that there is no online multiplayer. It would have been really great to take on other players in runs for the highest score, like an official street skating event, or even have people in the same level as you to compete for high score. I also wish that they would include a create-a-character. I'd love to use my own self-made character rather than the forced default. I'd say overall, this remake is nearly as good as Project 8(with a few shortcomings), which I consider the best of the franchise, and this certainly surpasses all other skating games. Now that this original THPS is in HD with new model and texture rendering, it's almost like a new game. You'll never want to go back to the old versions again... now can we get Project 8 on Steam too? :)

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Remember when the Squid totally beefed it?Well I'm the successor to the Squid and beefing it all day every day.  But still having a blast.  Seeing how far you can strain the balance meters and chaining tricks and pulling them off is still totally fun to this day.  I've only played 1, 2 and American Wasteland, and it's been so long since I've played them.  I forgot how fun these Pro Skater games were.  Customization is still there, newer characters (with females for you fellow waifu people).  Haven't gotten too far yet, but I'm hoping the stat builder is still there as well.The levels are exactly how I remember them, updated, and look great for what it is.  Quite a handful of the original tracks like "Saturday", "When Worlds Collide" and so forth are there.  Some were axed, and some new tracks were added that aren't really favorable to me.  Those who are also wondering, which disappoints me is, there's no track selection.  So if you want a song on repeat like in the originals, you'll have to wait until the game loops them around.  It's a bummer, but I only pay attention when a favorite of mine comes on.All in all, if you've played the old Pro Skaters on PS1/N64, like usual, snag it on a sale.  Fun little quick-play type game like the originals, that you can just go in and get out.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Done well:- HD face lift of classic levels- Aesthetically commendableDone poorly:- The engine- Post-release updates- Bug moderation- The soundtrack- The quality of the game for the priceRead on for a full and thorough review.A little background:I think I was proably around 6 or 7 years old when my aunt sent me Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 for the PS1. At the time, I think I may have been obsessed with both Tony Hawk, his franchise of games, and most of all his board company Birdhouse. I can't even remember why I started skateboarding at around the age of 5, but Tony Hawk was definitely my skateboarding idol. To be honest, I can't even remember how much I played THPS3. I played it straight for about 3 years. I don't ever recall playing any other game on my old PS1 slim. I'd beaten career mode with every single playable character, unlocked absolutely every unlockable item, and gained gold in all of the competitions. The most memorable aspect of the original THPS series were probably the soundtracks. After spending 3 years playing the game as a kid, I had learned pretty much every lyric to every song on the soundtracks. I didn't know who the artist was or what the song was called, but it you chucked the song on play today, I'd be able to sing along to it. Going back and playing the game now (I still have my PS1 copy), I noticed how stable the game's engine is. Despite the poor visuals (it WAS released in 2001), the game never felt chunky or buggy and always ran smoothly. I found this to be pretty consistent with all THPS titles, and this, coupled with Tony Hawk's fame and marketability, is what made the games so successful.Now:Fast forward 13 years. I think this was probably my first purcahse on Steam. As I had never really played on PCs before, I opted to use a controller. The controls are identical to the old layout on the PS1 and PS2 controllers - that I was happy about. After playing the games for awhile, the pushing of buttons becomes something as repetitive as changing gears in a car; you can do it quickly and without having to look down at what you're doing.I really enjoyed seeing a total facelift of the levels in the original games. During the development of the game, the original THPS engine was scrapped and a new one built. While an HD look is less important to me than the feel of the engine, the game does still look pretty nice. It gets let down by the fact that you can see textures render when you spawn. While this doesn't really affect gameplay, it just demonstrates that either this game was rushed, it had very little funding, or that they barely gave two craps when developing it.The game, as others have mentioned, it ridiculously buggy. I've found myself being thrown in the air and stretched to about four times my length while skating along flatground. I've had countless map breaks. When ollieing onto a rail to perform a grind, it's pretty common that the player will sink through the rail only to then assume the correct position. These bugs are tolerable, but when paying $15 dollars for a game, I don't expect to get something unfinished. Since I have bought the game, no updates or fixes have been implemented to attempt to fix these. It's a little disappointing that the developers pretty much abandoned the game after its first release as this could've had so much potential.I'd say the game's largest downfall is the 'soundtrack'. As this is a THPS remake, I'd expect it to be filled with the songs from the original games from artists like Alien Antfarm, The Ramones, AFI etc. Sadly, I don't recognise one song from the soundtrack. It seems poorly put together and none of the tracks flow well. Nothing about this remake's soundtrack is recogisable or memorable, and has left a bitter taste in my mouth.My advice? Sure, this game is fun to play when you're bored or hankering for a nostalgia hit. Is it worth the price? Should you get the DLC? It depnds if you are willing to pay for it, I suppose. I'd suggest you to buy it when and if it's ever on sale. I'd probably pay around 2-5 dollars for this game, not 15. My overall feelings about this game are, well, pretty "meh". This HD remake in no way does justice to the greatness of the original THPS series, but is an effective time passer.*If you're going to question whether the delayed loading of textures is due to my PC hardware, here's what I'm currently running.- CPU: Intel i5 4670- RAM: G. Skill 16GB Sniper kit- GPU: GTX 770- Motherboard: Asrock Z87 Extreme3- Power Supply: XFX 650W

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												( This is a no for anyone that's played the originals. If you never played the originals, this game will be fine. )This game isn't BAD on it's own, but it is bad compaired to the first 2-3 Tony Hawk's Pro Skater games it's supposedly remade from. Compaired to the original 2-3 THPS games:Pros:better graphicsCons: stranger physics than the originalsWorse trick connection (landing tricks)Wallrides are MUCH harder to perform due to odd physicsVERY few levels, this was AMAZINGLY dissappointing.  (the first THPS has as many levels as this has, and this is supposed to be a remake of the first 2-3 games combined.)NO MULTIPLAYER! NO ONLINE, NO LAN CONNECTION, AND NO SPLITSCREEN. This was the worst part, playing with friends was the best part of these games.(the not so bad) No character creation.Very low music, even at max (and very FEW musics, they get very repetitive)Very few characters to choose fromEverything about this seems watered down and lazy. They spent more time making the graphics better than actually making it play like it should. Everything seems like it was rushed, and they definately messed up by having no multiplayer support at all.TL;DR Game doesn't feel like THPS should, it definately doesn't play like the original 2-3, and the lack of levels and multiplayer ruined it. If you're a fan of the originals, don't get this. If you never played the originals, this game will play like a generic wacky skater game, not a bad buy for so cheap.(This is coming from a Tony Hawk game veteran, I played all 4 THPS games, both THUG games , THAW, and Project 8)

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												This game was developed by Robomodo instead of the original Neversoft, but it is still published by Activision. It is more of a highlight reel put together by fans of the franchise than a 100% port of the original. That being said, it is still very much Tony Hawk Pro Skater and has hours of playability.The base game has seven levels from THPS 1 & 2 (Warehouse, School II, Hangar, Mall, Venice Beach, Downhill Jam, Marseilles), and the DLC adds three huge maps from THPS 3 (Airport, LA, Canada). An awesome feature they used was that they locked all of the levels, making you play and complete the challenges in order to progress to the next stage. The hidden S-K-A-T-E's are all still in their original places, as well as the VHS's, except they have been changed to DVD's.Purchasing the DLC also adds the ability to revert during combos on all maps, allowing you to carry them for a longer amount of time. Additional content includes four new skaters: Steve Caballero, Geoff Rowley, James Hetfield and Robert Trujillo of Metallica. Most of the complaints I see are about wonky physics, but the franchise has always had wonky physics. I booted up my original THPS2 on console and it was pretty damn wonky. But that is what added to the fun and charm of the franchise, at least to me. However, there unfortunately are no multiplayer game modes, and there is also no level editor.Still highly recommended for skateboarding fans and fans of the franchise!

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Remember that classic, awesome skateboarding game Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 (and the first and third game surrounding it that were also enjoyable)? Well, Tony Hawk's Pro Skater "HD" upon the first cursory glance gives you the false impression that it will offer a blast to the past - at the very least a rough approximation of the gameplay that you grew up loving in those games. It does not in any way, shape or form. I seem to recall the console version being better but I have no idea for sure seeing the demo had a timer and it was about three seconds. This pile of dogshit offers the experience of bailing over and over again for no apparent reason and watching your glitchy ragdoll fly into the air like a retardad astronaut, gaining speed out of nowhere after moving at one mile per hour on your board up on to a slightly angled surface. You can very quickly rack up enough cash to upgrade your stats and they appear to have absolutely no effect whatsoever on resolving the inability to land at a slightly less than perfect angle and not fall face first into the pavement. The gameplay is in fact so poor that it is excrutiatingly difficult to pull off badass chain combos in the manner that you could in the games this one is attempting to emulate. By the time you adjust to it, you'll have lost several thousand brain cells. Do yourself a favor and go pick up a used copy of Project 8 or American Wasteland - the last two real Tony Hawk games by Neversoft with extremely solid, crisp gameplay. This is absolutely worthless.In other words, this game ♥♥♥♥ing SUCKS.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												If you're like I was and are jonesing for some Tony Hawk's Pro Skater gameplay after not having a console around for many years, then this game will sort of fill the void (at least for a short time). The physics situation in this version is straight up atrocious, with completely ridiculous bails where your body will fly in the exact opposite direction it should. The skating isn't nearly as smooth as THPS3 or 4 (my personal favorites) and feels more like the N64 versions with just better graphics. Another issue that is just absurd, is landing in vert. To get a perfect landing, it only looks to see if you land at the exact same angle that you took off, which makes no sense if you are traversing a gap horizontally. Terrible.The maps don't feel alive, there is a distinct lack of atmosphere with little or no NPCs around.If you can grab it on sale and really need a THPS fix, then go for it. But make sure you have a controller because it's awful to play with a keyboard. At full price I wouldn't recommend. So my "Yes I would recommend" is more like a "yes, but only if you realllllly miss THPS."

												It's very rare that a game comes along that I can get lost in... those games can bring you back to being a child and allow you just leave behind the day to day of your life for just a moment as you reconnect with what it means to be akid and just have a good time tearing up some video games. You turn on a hugely anticipated HD remake, hear those familiar tunes that were once lost the corners of your mind, grab Bob Burnquist... my favorite skater :-)... and let muscle memory shift into overdrive as you find yourself shredding the pavement. I could imagine myself almost feeling hte wind soaring through my hair as I pulled off stunts thatnobody oculd even fathom, tkaing skateboarding to heights it's never been.Well... this is not that game. This piece of flaming garbage is nothing like the name suggests. The graphics are worse than my ED, the controls are looser than my teeth, and skate roster is barer than my nuts. Where the ♥♥♥♥ is Bob Burnquist, Tony? Is Chad Muska hanging out wiht him because I don't him either, Tony? Nobody wants to play as Riley Hawk, Tony. Wanna know how many people even ♥♥♥♥ing know who Riley Hawk is, Tony? I don't have a number in mind, but I'm sure it's low as hell, Tony.In short, ♥♥♥♥ing Tony Hawk and ♥♥♥♥ the Free World. #313forlife

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												I remeber playing the original Tony Hawk games as a kid and it was one of the first games I have ever played as a kid and I still remeber the fond memories of the games to this day. The moment I saw that the games were going to be remade in HD I freaked out and I was so hyped to play the games and relive some good memories. This game seriously delivered with some pretty good controls, excellent graphics, fantastic soundtrack, and generally brings back nostalgia. This game has tons of replay value if you want to max the stats out of your skaters or just beat career mode over and over again. I've done that and it is so fun to play the original Tony Hawk games again.Although this game was good, there was some flaws that really stand out. The fact that create-a-skater is gone and some other cool unlocks are gone (like Spiderman in THPS2). They dont have 2-player splitscreen or even creating a park isn't even here. There are also game glitches and clipping that is really bothersome to me. Some players have argued that there is a restriction on resolutions that you have to edit it in the games files for it to fit their proper resolutions which is a problem.Those things aside, I highly recommend this game if you've played the three Tony Hawk's Pro Skaters and want to play the levels again in HD. I give this game a 9.5/10 because the complaints I've given are minor and don't really relate to me and I love the nostalgic value this game has given me.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Yeah...I mean, it's okay. I wasn't really expecting it to be an exact port, or anything, but I did expect a litle more...effort to be put into it? I don't know. I only spent like $8 on it, so it's not a total loss. The bad psyhics kind of ruin it, but that's just me. It's probably because I'm just remembering HOW GOOD it was back on Xbox. There's too many let downs for me to recommend it, however. For one: the psyhics. The bailing animation is...bad. Also, the fact that it offers no controller explantion? Did they REALLY expect people to play a SKATING GAME with a KEYBOARD and MOUSE??? I didn't think so, but apparently they did. I REALLY wish I still had my Xbox, in all honesty. Maybe I could emulate it...Anyways. It has nice graphics and music, but I'd seriously tell you to not get it at full price. It might be one of the rare times...where...I kind of want a refund. If you ever (which is HIGHLY UNLIKELY) get the chance to play the orginal ones on an Xbox, do it. I bet (I KNOW) it'd be a LOT better. I've played some pretty bad remakes, so this is rather dissapointing. I...guess, if you want, get it on sale, I wouldn't recommend it though. There exists Tony Haw: Proving Ground for the Wii, that is REALLY good except for the Wiimote controls. Just go get that. It's more expensive, but it would be 10x the fun as...this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Play Underground 2 or American Wasteland on an emulator.  Trust me.  Just do it.  Forget graphics, forget slightly better physics.  It doesn't matter.  This game is so lacking in content and so short that I can't believe it even exists.  How could a game as open, free and creative as Underground 2 exist when something like this came ten years after?  It is made by different people, but REALLY.  This is a bad joke.  You can't make a game in a series that is 15 years old and give it less content that the 3rd game had.  Yes, Pro Skater 3 is about twice as good as this game.  I'm not joking.  I've played Tony Hawk games my entire life and these past few games are like a bad dream.  I can't wrap my head around this game being real when it doesn't have create-a-skater, park editor, trick editor, 1/8 of the tricks of even underground 1, and nothing to do expect classic 2:00 mode.  I fear for the game industry if anyone really thinks products like this are acceptable.  This game should have been a demo for the real game, which would have been 10 times better.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												I have mixed feelings regarding this game. While I don't remember the old THPS games too well, I can easily say there's plenty of stuff missing in this HD version. The worst part is lack of multiplayer, it could make the game so much more fan if you could compete online against other people... Also, I've been encountering some occasional glitches that I don't remember ever happening in the old games. Still, I do feel like recommending this game, because I don't think there's a better skating game for a PC out there. It made me feel a bit nostalgic and brought up some good memories. It's highly recommended to own an xbox controller to play this, but I believe you can manage to play on a keyboard just fine.

												This game is somewhat enjoyable, but it seriously lacks something. There isn't really a storyline, which this game series really needs more of, and the overall game is rather dissapointingly short. The gameplay is rough especially it's 'accurate' physics and the slightest bit off of landing will send you sprawling to the ground bleeding, which is infuriating, and outside of the the physics, you can't modify the controls as for which button is asigned to which and is hard to accomodate. The praphics/asthetics are weak and could use some major redoing if they decide to ever republish this game. So overall, this game was a letdown and not one which I would recommend getting. I would rate this game as a 4 out of 10.

												Here I amdoing everything I canHolding on to what I ampretending I'm a Superman[...]Take a step to freedomYou and her against this cruel worldTake a breath of shelter and exhaleTrust and allegianceLiberate yourself from hellIt's just another Saturday[...]Tell us where you're from,what you want to become.And we'll say if you're OK.Where did you go to school?Right answer and you're cool.[...]'Cause I don't care where I belong no more.What we share or not I will ignore.And I won't waste my time fitting in.'Cause I don't think contrast is a sin.[...]There's a place where everyone can be happy.It's the most beautiful place in the whole ♥♥♥♥ing world.It's made of candy canes and planes and bright red choo-choo trains,And the meanest little boys and the most innocent little girls,[...]F*CK, I should play the game and not only listen to the music!!!So here I amgrowing older all the timelooking older all the timefeeling younger in my mind[...]DAMMIT!!I can't help it but the soundtrack of this series was always great.Additionally to this HD Remaster I have to say that the graphic updates of the old THPS 1 & 2 maps are pretty nice.Controls are like the old THPS games.They should have added more achievements and career targets to challange the player.The extra game modes are nice but also short-lived and not as great as the single player campaign/career.If you don't want to de-dust your old PlayStation1 it is worth buying (especially when it's on sale).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD is a good game (and a fine remake).To address some of the issues that appear in the negative reviews :- Poor Control. This was an issue that I had when first playing the game with my Logitech Dual Action. The game remained 'playable', however the game had issues when the imputs occured too quickly. Later on I switched to using a Dualshock 3 with ScpServer and have had no issues since (having no problem with clearing all objectives, I refuse to acknowledge 'poor control' as a reason to dismiss this game).-  Bugs	. Occasionally I have seen some graphical bugs with the textures, as they become blurry for brief moments during gameplay. While I understand that graphical bugs can defeat the purpose of an 'HD remake' for some, please note that this issue rarely occured and had no effect the gameplay itself. Another bug is the result of wonky crash physics that sometimes cause the character to ragdoll or bounce upon wipeout. While some might think this as a bug, it is only experienced once the character has fallen and broken their trick combo. Rest assured that these bugs are only a minor annoyance and will not affect your performance in doing tricks or completing objectives.- No Multiplayer	. Yeah, I can agree that this sucks. Seeing as how multiplayer was in the ps3/360 port, I don't know why It wasn't implemented in the PC version. I would hope for a multiplayer mod, but it's unlikely that will ever happen.-  Waah my nostalgia!. Despite the game only containing a few levels from each of the THPS 1-3 games, it remains unchanged from the original games despite the graphical improvements (as an 'HD remake' should have). The music, level design, objectives, skaters and boards are all the same (with the expection of the secret area inside the school not being available. If you can't experience nostalgia here then it seems you might not have had any experience with the original games at all, or your 'nostalgia' has limited you from enjoying this game.The game also provides plenty of extra game modes that the original games did not, allowing for extended replay value. I had a blast playing this game and could reccomend to anyone looking to play THPS in HD.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Tony Hawk's Pro Skater® HD: Not the same, but is that really a bad thing?The original Tony Hawks in no means had any form of realism involved, infact It was more of an Arcade-like high scoring game in which you tried to beat your best combo every time you played. Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD brings a new engine into play where you will start to think the game is simply buggy or broken. This game took me around 45 minutes until I started hitting sick combos like I did back in the day with Underground. I can now say that I am enjoying this game for what it is, a revitalized Tony Hawk game with a better engine. Now with a new engine comes a lot of problems. I started realizing very quickly that when you try to flip trick off certain rails, you bail 90% of the time. These rails I have now marked down in my head and I now simply ollie off them into a manual to make up for the loss of points. If you never played a Tony Hawk game then this is not a big deal, but for me that is lost points on a line I had going, and it will make you highly upset when you bail off of a highscore. The challenge system makes you unlock all the maps in career mode. You must complete set amount of challenges to unlock new maps. I have already unlocked majority and it is great to see classic maps placed in there purest form. I still remember all the old warehouse tricklines that I was able to do back in the day. Final Verdict:This game is not the same as all the previous classic Tony Hawk games. But for someone who is new to the series, this is a good start. If you want to re-visit older Tony Hawk games, you will begin to apreciate everything this new installment has taught you. I went back to unerground yesterday and I felt better then I was when I played it at 15. 7/10 - The fact that I cant perfectly land lines that I was able to do before really upsets me. But really this will be great for anyone who wants to give the Tony Hawks franchise a shot. It will take you a while but soon you will be getting 500,000 plus score on every map.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2012
												Отличное HD переиздание на несколько вечеров. Опять же, почему при выходе все ругались и плевались не понятно, ведь переиздание гораздо лучше, чем 3 последние игры от Тони, которые с каждой последующей, катились всё ниже и ниже. Графика весьма на уровне, не режет глаза, а физика, практически один в один с 1-ой Playstation, что лично для меня - огромный плюс! Кататься так же приятно, как и 15 лет назад, взял в руки джой и через 5 минут уже комбо под 100-200 тысяч навертел, это как ездить на велосипеде, если научился, никогда уже не разучишься.Но когда-то, серия была на пике славы, особенно первые 4 номерных части, от них игре и достался почти весь контент  -  уровни, но добавили маловато, в основном из первой и второй, и то, только самые популярные этапы.Какое-то время ждал DLC, вышло только одно, опять же с парой уровней, печально. Почему нельзя было издать старые игры полностью, в нормальном разрешение да с ачивками, не понятно. В итоге кушаем солянку, да не полную миску, а половину. Покататься, трюки вспомнить, понастальгировать, самое оно. В остальном - всё как в стареньких ТХ, набери очки, гринд над платформой, собери слово скейт и т.д. Был удивлён новой, приятной музыкой в саундтреке, добавил пару песен в плейлист, мой фаворит Middle Class Rut – USA.Без геймпада даже не включайте!Оценка 8 + Если вам понравился обзор, подписывайтесь на мою кураторскую страничку, где я постоянно пишу и рекомендую самые разные игры! Вступайте в группу Вконтакте, там публикую заметки об игровых новостях и кино. А также присоединяйтесь к каналу на YouTube, читайте, смотрите, комментируйте и зовите друзей! http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6866569/ https://vk.com/pu4eglaz_grouphttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZzG-NJrvDZcetL8Yn5n9Hg

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Not what I was hoping for. The Tony Hawk's series has had a steady decline in quality over the past years and this HD remake was supposed to bring back life to the games. However, it really fails at that. The only thing this game offers is a graphical update of some old, classic Tony Hawk's levels (and some, which suck...seriously? Downhill Jam?) but fails to deliver a good interpretation of the old-school gameplay. Firstly, the physics are a mess. I'm not sure if they tried to blend arcade and realistic gameplay but a lot of the time you find yourself bailing in situations that would be a normal, if somewhat sketchy, landing in previous games. Yes, in real life if you landed like that you would eat a good serving of concrete but not in an old-school Tony Hawk game. We have the EA Skate series for realistic skateboarding frustration, we didn't need that in an arcade skateboarding game. Something else I found awful were the insane difficulty spikes and declines. Of course, this could be contributed to my complete lack of gaming skill but it just feels like they randomly picked some levels and threw them in there in no particular order.My biggest gripe - NO MULTIPLAYER! Not even local multiplayer, let alone online. And this is a big problem, because while the game is mediocre if could have been pretty fun with some people around.Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD has 3 good things in it - a pretty good soundtrack, the warehouse level and Chris Cole. Other than that, you're better off getting one of the old games for that nostalgic kick we all need. Only get this if it's stupidly cheap in a sale. It's a good recreation of the originl games' look but it fails at what's most important - making the skateboarding gameplay fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Okay so I saw all the bad reviews for this game and watching it on youtube doesnt do me justice at all so I decided to buy the game and try it out because I am a big fan of playing THPS 2 on N64. Its not going to be good...1. Lack of character varietyIf you played all the games then you would know that this character list is barely half of what THPS2 was which doesnt make sense to not put in everyone but thats how it was.2. PHYSICSThis game is apparently "Real" meaning you dont get insane air or go really fast when you start doing tricks which is a HUGE downer because THPS was a fast paced game and this game is the opposite. Its more like a real skate game where you cant chain multiple moves like crazy but instead be more careful of overdoing it which isnt fun at all. I do not like the new gravity or physics or whatever makes this game so slow and heavy.3. No career mode?THPS2 had a good career mode where it made you feel like you unlocked something new but instead its just "Do this and that and now the next level and do this and that repeat" its boring and not immersive at all and also frustration because of how the game plays and feels. Its not like the old games at all.4. Music??This is a modern game and yet back in the 90's they had the technology to select the track you wanted to play in the game yet in this modern game you cant select the music.... enough said5. Levels??Wheres new york or philly or Mexico??? This game should have everything of all the games combined but its just a sloppy creation of nothing special.6. Playing the gameOverall, I didnt enjoy this for the time I played it for. I tried to complete all goals for the next stage and nothing happened at the last staged and I do not want to 100% with how bad the game controls and feels. I cannot find any positives other than it looks OKAY but not great at all.I most likely wont play this again and if you want a 100% choice on to buy this game or not. Dont buy it and get some cool indie game instead.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2012
												Tony Hawk's Pro Scater HD is a good remake of 1st and 2nd game in the series as it brings back those old times when these games rocked so much. You can choose from Tony Hawk himself and other great scaters to play on different skating tracks. There are alot of cool moves you can do as well as buy new ones with money you earn doing some challenges for 7 maps. It's all old school arcade style gameplay. You can perform different acrobatic moves and earn points but if you crash you will lose all your combo. There are also some other modes to play but they are not so entertaining. The soundtrack is great adn never bores at all. Although there is no "Create a Park" feature as were in some other games so you have only 7 different tracks from old games and Post dlc will add a bit more from 3rd game. Final word goes to PC port. It's done bad adn no video settings. All in all it's a good blast from the past, but better experience is on consoles. 6/10

content:
Posted: April 8, 2013
												Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD is a high-definition re-release featuring classic levels and music from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1 and 2, with the DLC you will also have access to some levels of THPS 3.THPSHD looks great, the levels and characters are upgraded with sharp visuals and fresh content. The gameplay has been left almost completely untouched, but the Levels feel just a little different (not better or worse).The game has no option to change the key bindings, you have to edit some ini files with an editor to get a good controlling. It's also missing many key features from old THPS games, like a level editor or a character creator.There’s no local multiplayer and unlike the XBOX version, the PC version also has no online multiplayer.There are also some technical issues, like sometimes your character falls down for no reason or clipping issues are also present; it is possible to fall through a level.Sound 9/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 6/10Atmosphere 7/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

												This game is absolutely fantastic.  For lovers of Tony hawk 1, 2 and the PS1 versions of 3 and 4 - This game is for you! The physics and animations are smooth and PC runs at a solid 60. The game is vert vibrant and the upscale looks great.For people who want to purchase this game, get it on PS3 (Preferred) or X360. number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Please ignore the negative reviews. I really cannot understand where these people are coming from. In fact, a lot of them have < 1 hour playtime so I am not sure their opinions are relevant. I played THS, THPS2 and THPS3 back when they released on PS1 and this is a great way to revisit those games. They have really captured the feel of them. With the remastering it is like you are playing both a new game and the game you grew up loving.This features some of the classic tracks from the originals, all my favourites at least. Warehouse, Hangar, School II, Marseille etc.There is a DLC with THPS3 tracks on too like Canada and LA. Which brings me to another point. All the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about revert being included as a DLC when it "should have been in from the start". This game was originally a remastering of the first 2 games. Not 3. Revert was not in the first 2 games. But you probably didn't actually play the originals. The developers bowed to the beggars and whiners and released revert in the DLC and were good enough to release 3 THPS3 traks with it and the price isn't outlandish like a lot of other DLC out there. Yes there's no track creator but there is a host of brand new game modes, all of which are pretty damn fun.If I could give it one criticism it's that split-screen multiplayer would have been great. But that by no means qualifies this as a bad game. Look at the sidebar over there, it says Single-player, you know what you're getting going in.The soundtrack is as amazing as ever, No Cigar, You, May 16, all my personal favourites from the original games as well as a few welcome additions.Ignore the babies. If you liked the original you'll like this.P.S. I have been playing with a controller and this review is based on that play. I cannot speak for M+K controls.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												When reading this review, please be aware that I only feel this way because I'm an old school Tony Hawk's player. If you haven't played any Tony Hawk-games before, this review isn't necessarily for you.So, I really don't have that much to say about this game. I didn't even have to play it for more than 6 minutes to realize it wasn't anything I had thought about. Basically the only Tony Hawk-games I've played are Tony Hawk's American Wasteland and the Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 Demo. Now those games were certainly a whole bunch of fun to play, as their game mechanics were awesome. Those games, of course on todays standards, are buggy games with poor graphics. This is the reason why I thought 'hey, this game looks like an improved version of the other Tony Hawk-games'. Oh boy was i wrong. The game mechanics are utter crap, and indeed, the only thing improved are the graphics. I would honestly choose American Wasteland over this new school version any time.2/10

Posted: September 21, 2012
												Instead of beating the dead horse that is skateboarding games Tony Hawk has gone back to basics with a remake of the original game to carry pro skater title. While everything bad about the newest games has been removed of course so were some of the improvements. Grinds & manuals can no longer be augmented mid trick and the segways from vertical to ground tricks are absent as well. Aside from a few minor changes and an HD repainting it's the same N64 classic you knew and loved (with an unfortunate reminder of downhill jam by a map of the same name to make sure too much fun isn't had).All in all it's a great piece of retro revival from a genre that was killed by those that made it popular. If you enjoyed this game fifteen years ago it's still as much fun today even if it does boil down to little more than a rerelease. If you're feeling nostalgic it's a great play as long as you don't expect much more than the original delivered.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												TL;DR: I don't really recommend it because it doesn't even live upto the standards of 12 years ago. The physics and board handling are pretty dire for a modern skateboarding simulation game.I have been a fan of the Tony Hawk's games since the early 2000's when I first got my hands on the original Tony Hawk's Pro Skater (or Tony Hawk's Skateboarding as it was known in the UK and other PAL regions)  back in roughly 2000. I have played every PlayStation instalment since the first game with the exception of the HD games and the motion controlled Ride and Shred games.Recently I have been emulating the hell out of all these games using PCSX2 here on my PC and FPSE on my OUYA so I can make direct comparisons here and not rely on 10 year old memories. These games are older and they are outright better.Once you get over the questionable menu and HUD design (is Clarendon really the most appropriate typeface for the UI here?), no XBOX button prompts when using a gamepad,  the lack of some of my favourite pro skaters (no Chad Muska or  Mike Vallely) and most importantly the game's physics and board handling.The physics and board handling really let me down, that is to me the most important parts of any skateboard simulation game out there. I will tell you the game handles a lot like Grind Session did back in 2000. Between the ollies, grinding and the bails. It feels like a game from 14-15 years ago gameplay wise.  As for the Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2, 3 and 4 which this game is designed to pay homage to, they handle so much better and they are so much older. Don't believe me, give them a whirl. If you can get over the outdated graphics, the gameplay is still very solid on those games.There are a few positives though.  First off, the game's UI while being hit and miss, does make a few hits. I like the addition of a level map in the pause menu, although it isn't that useful when I have played all of the levels so many times in the past (there are NO original levels in this game). Also I like the progress meter for the goals which is think is pretty sleek in this version. I like how it greys out the missing SKATE letters.Also the graphics and visual effects are pretty nice, helped by the power of the Unreal Engine 3. It is interesting to see old levels that haven't had a modern graphical update for the last decade get some love, I like daylight effects used in the Warehouse level and I like the addition of a dome in the Mall level from THPS, it's a nice touch.Also I love the soundtrack. A few of the classics from the original THPS games have made it to the game's OST including Millencolin - No Cigar, Public Enemy feat. - Bring the Noise and Powerman 5000 - When World's Collide. They always sound great, classic songs. In addition there are new songs too to make a nice balanced playlist.The addition of achievements ,albeit just 15 is a nice addition and will definitely motivate me to continue playing this game for some time.  I'll see how many I'll get before I am bored.Finally the lack of multiplayer is understandable for a $9.99 (£8.99) title. It would have been a nice addition to play these levels with local or online multiplayer with game modes like Horse, Free Skate and Graffiti. But I don't blame Robomodo for omitting it, probably due to time and budget restraints.To conclude, the game just doesn't handle well enough to give me a nostalgia kick. It irritates me more than it excites me. I guess it's up to Neversoft to make a solid Tony Hawk game like they did in the past all the way up to Project 8 (which was alright). This game doesn't get a recommendation from me, because the other games emulate perfectly and you should be playing them instead.

Posted: October 9, 2012
												As an HD remake, this mashup of THPS1&2 makes everything much smoother and prettier while still keeping gameplay the same. In addition to Career and Free Skate mode, it adds Projectives, Bighead Endurance, and Hawkman modes to lengthen the lives of the admittedly short level list. More levels, characters, and moves are coming in the THPS3 DLC.Sadly, there are no create-a-modes. There are also very few PC customization options in-game, requiring you to look up how to change settings online through the game's text files.It's a great start, though it'll need a few DLC to match the amount of content we've come to expect from Tony Hawk games. Now, if only we could get this hooked up to the Steam Workshop and creative tools, we'd have an untapped goldmine on our hands. That, and expanding the short soundtrack / adding the option for user tracks.I'm having great fun kicking my old scores to the curb btw.

Posted: September 20, 2012
												Being a fan of the THPS series for Playstation as a kid growing up a good 14 years ago, I can't even express how excited I was to see this being released. It's bringing back so many memories. Once I finish this here, I'll probably dog out my old PS1 disk and give it a go again. It's been about 3 years now since I last played THPS2.- GREAT improvement in maps graphics and details. Changes from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 have been made, so I noticed in the Hanger level (so far I'm only at lv2), that the hidden room with the helicopter isn't there (at least, not that I've found yet. Still trying to get used to playing this on laptop and not with a controller... wallrides are tricky for me on here).- Different skaters to play as, new and old. Including Hawk's son, Riley.- Classic game modes. Collect S-K-A-T-E etc.- Selected music from THPS2 with some new additions. The soundtrack is just overall fantastic.Recommended to any fan of the series.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Pretty good game depending on who's playing it. Somone new to the series would most likely enjoy this remake but others familiar with the original series tony hawk's pro skater 1,2,3,4 and THUG series would most likely be disappointed. The game is more of a remake of 1,2,3,4 on a new engine with missing essential elements to the original series. Acid drops, spine transfers, manual tricks  (EX truckstand, casper) are completly missing. Players also looking for the THUG experience with a new story should stay away from this game or expect less. Setting options are also a downside to this game. Not having any other settings is also a downside. This clearly show's the game is a straight console port looking exactly like the PS3 version. This is not a real downside but being the PC version I expected a bit more. Also the sound setting for the Effects are completly broken I found my self turning down the SFX volume yet having the sound effects of Cars and breaking object completly blasting my ears even with everything else turned down. Ended up turning off the sound manualy in windows. Speaking of sound berely having any tracks may cause some people to just mute their in game music and play their own which is what I do but for $10 bucks its unexceptable. Also older Tony Hawk games like pro skater 4 and Underground having legendary sound tracks I expected more from this remake. Over all its an Okay game 7/10. Maybe worth $10 to some but for me its worth like $5 bucks which is what I got it for during the summer sale.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I just HAD to have this game. A long time ago, a friend of mine owned THPS on his PS1. It was fun to play every now and then when I visited, but he became amazing at the game. Watching him get all the achievements was frustrating and fun. I was happy with my Nintendo collection, for sure, but I always wanted to own THPS on a console that would make it more responsive and, especially, look better; So when I saw THPSHD, I knew right away that the game was gonna be a real hair pulling, multi-screaming event in my life.. and it hasn't disappointed at all. The down-side is the DLC of James Hetfield. I for one do NOT like Jim at all and it's an interesting element to know I have to complete the game with him one of these days. If I'm smart, I'll stop all my other work and just go do The Het straight away to get him finished. The soundtrack is a bit lacking (as are the options for music..), but that's just me being a fool. The game is all about "challenge" and THPSHD certainly delivers on THAT front. I've been having an awesome time playing the game. I think just about anyone who is into unlocking stuff and perfecting game challenges will like this game. In its own cohesive way it's a sport/puzzle game. It has (for me) just the right type of frustration; it is a real "damn.. so close" and "WHAT!? NO WAY!? I WENT RIGHT THROUGH THAT! RIPPED OFF!" kinda game. It instills that wonderful fun of having to stay focussed and confident - you'll end up staying on a really difficult section of the game just to GET IT DONE. Eventually, the game opens some really fun cheat modes (which is always cool) and your mind can get confused as to exactly WHY a player should buy all those skateboards - but, so help me, I need everything in the game.. just to see if I can do it. I think it's a fantastic rendition of the older types; loads of fun and frustration. I'd give it a 4 out of 5, but due to Hetfield, I'll give it a 3.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												This game brings back the fun and addictive gameplay that kind of disappeared after Underground 2. It mixes together the two first Pro Skater games (and adds a little bit of 3 in its DLC, which rocks) and brings them to HD.It has all the old objectives from the old games' respective levels, as well as other modes, such as the Projectives mode, which gives the veterans some extra-challenging objectives. If you liked the original Pro Skater games, you'll most likely love this game too.Some of the few criticisms I did have with the game was that in order to adjust graphical settings, you must go and fiddle with the INI files in the game folder (which is almost a must, since V-sync is off by default and the screen tearing is painful).There are also some strange glitches that tend to occasionally screw up a large combo you're building up by making you trip on seemingly nothing or just ending the combo abruptly (though this happens rarely enough for it to not matter much).All in all, old fans and newcomers alike should get a kick out of this game.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												6/10This game is alright, it feels like a mashup of THPS 1-3 with some new skaters. The game itself is visually appealing, but I am dissapointed that the only option in the graphics menu is the ability to alter the resolution, this is a little shabby for a modern PC port. The selection of levels is OK, although personally I feel they could have added a few more to the mix, such as downtown minneapolis from THPS1, Skate street from THPS2. My only problem with the levels is that some of them haven't been adapted to the new game engine, meaning that certain gaps and goals are now more difficult to achieve than in the original games, one of the main examples of this is the venice beach level in which certain gaps and goals have had their difficulty unneccessarily increased, this down to the fact that your skater moves slower than in the classic games. The new engine is nice and it feels like they tried to emulate the THPS3 engine but with more realistic movement, however the game will sometimes throw you off your board even if you don't bail, this can be annoying when trying to get a high score. I'm not too bothered about the lack of multiplayer but local multiplayer/splitscreen would have been an asset here. I'm also dissapointed that you can't dismount your board in order to look around a level in order to find certain goals like in the THUG games. In conclusion it has potential but it feels rushed, it feels like they spent more time porting the levels and making all the movements seem hyper realistic that they forgot to see whether or not their game actually worked properly.tl;dr, buy this if its on sale like I did, otherwise stick to the older games as THUG, THUG-2 and THAW all feature updated versions of the classic levels

												Fun bit of reminiscing for those old enough to remember this on PS1 & PC back in the last century. Do not purchase this unless you have a game controller. The XBOX 360 controller works well. It is pretty much unplayable on keyboard unless you are a masochist, really, don't even try.So, I realise that with remakes there are fanatical cannon dorks who want you to stay true to the original, but really, this is not one of those situations. Leaving out the tranny revert was a mistake; landing on the ramp transition and doing a revert into a manual is a feature from later games that this really should have. Only the 3 levels in the DLC pack apparently have that. The other major linking trick missing is the wall plant. Wall rides are there, great, but the wall plant lets you fly head on at a wall, pause momentarily and then effectively bounce off and head back the way you came. These two tricks allow for very long high scoring runs, and should have been coded in. I mean, it's not like Devs had to create the game from scratch right ;) (Yes I am downplaying the work involved in updating a game's textures and resolution to HD, but think about the level design and and the other stuff they didn't need to do).  There is also no way out of a bad ramp exit. If you fly off the side of the ramp, your body is effectively horizontal to the ground and you are going to stack. I am sure I recall later games letting you lean and correct so you can land flat. That's a minor gripe, because it only happens when you've stuffed up, but it's frustrating because as soon as you do it you know it's going to be bad. Finally, it is a little glitchtastic sometimes. You are prone to ragdolling into the fourth dimension, which can happen when you are just trying to grind something or wall ride and don't hit it quite right. It's like you hit a pebble or something and then fly 5 stories into the air. Something is not quite right with the physics of that. Apart from that the game is pretty stable. It's not like it crashes but its a glitch. Still a fun game 20 years later

												A brilliant remake of the original THPS, however I have faced a few bugs in the game, including several occasions where I would get stuck in the environment (whether in be between a railing and half-way into a wall) and would keep on bailing, followed by falling through the floor every now and then. Posted: May 4, 2014
												Not a bad game, per se. It's what expected in terms of gameplay: the old TH games - in HD. What I didn't expect, and probably should have look more into before buying, is the lack of levels in this version. There are only a pawltry few (6, if I remember offhand) and I blazed through them very quickly. They were mostly the same, except that what were originally competition levels are now just standard goal ones, which is partly why I was so surprised to find I had completed the last level; There is no climax to this game, no giant halfpipe/running with the bulls competition.There are fair number of bugs as well, and even with a controller the controls seemed off.Knowing that now, I wouldn't recommend getting this game unless you can snag it for super cheap. Like, maybe 80% off.

												So I bought on a whim because it was on sale.  I spent countless hours playing the original Tony Hawk Pro Skater games on the PSX and Dreamcast.  This game feels every bit as good as all of those, the only problem... it is missing the key functionality that made it really enjoyable for me.  You cannot create your own skater.  This is a fatal flaw, because I liked being able to create my own skater and assign the attibutes however I saw fit.  From the standpoint of good old Pro Skater fun, this game has it... with my 360 controller and in 1080p it felt great revisiting the levels I knew so well.But the game just doesn't feel right without the "RP" aspect of being able to create your own characters.

Posted: October 9, 2012
												As an HD remake, this mashup of THPS1&2 makes everything much smoother and prettier while still keeping gameplay the same. In addition to Career and Free Skate mode, it adds Projectives, Bighead Endurance, and Hawkman modes to lengthen the lives of the admittedly short level list. More levels, characters, and moves are coming in the THPS3 DLC.Sadly, there are no create-a-modes. There are also very few PC customization options in-game, requiring you to look up how to change settings online through the game's text files.It's a great start, though it'll need a few DLC to match the amount of content we've come to expect from Tony Hawk games. Now, if only we could get this hooked up to the Steam Workshop and creative tools, we'd have an untapped goldmine on our hands. That, and expanding the short soundtrack / adding the option for user tracks.I'm having great fun kicking my old scores to the curb btw.

Posted: December 7, 2014
												I went into this game blind. The only Tony Hawk game I ever played was THPS4 (and Ride, but that was dreadful.) I bought the game and the Revert pack at the same time. My pros and cons:Pros:Fluid and fast gameplayGreat character and level design (but it's a remake of THPS1 and 2, so that's a gibbon.)The cheats are delicious fun, including one that lets you play as classic Tony Hawk.The controls feel VERY natural, especially with a controllerCustomizable boards and unlockable characters make getting money funCons:Very glitchy. My board sometimes went sailing off into space and I go the opposite direction.The game likes to cheat with the big drops, telling you right before you fall on your face.The game is basically inaccessible to the newcomers without cheats.Goals become extremely hard in career mode. It asked me to get 3 roll call rails, but I couldn't tell what they were until I grinded on them.With all of that said, it's a very fun game. Many people might disagree, but I had a lot of fun, and I think you will too.Overall Score: 8/10

Posted: January 9, 2015
												Fun bit of reminiscing for those old enough to remember this on PS1 & PC back in the last century. Do not purchase this unless you have a game controller. The XBOX 360 controller works well. It is pretty much unplayable on keyboard unless you are a masochist, really, don't even try.So, I realise that with remakes there are fanatical cannon dorks who want you to stay true to the original, but really, this is not one of those situations. Leaving out the tranny revert was a mistake; landing on the ramp transition and doing a revert into a manual is a feature from later games that this really should have. Only the 3 levels in the DLC pack apparently have that. The other major linking trick missing is the wall plant. Wall rides are there, great, but the wall plant lets you fly head on at a wall, pause momentarily and then effectively bounce off and head back the way you came. These two tricks allow for very long high scoring runs, and should have been coded in. I mean, it's not like Devs had to create the game from scratch right ;) (Yes I am downplaying the work involved in updating a game's textures and resolution to HD, but think about the level design and and the other stuff they didn't need to do).  There is also no way out of a bad ramp exit. If you fly off the side of the ramp, your body is effectively horizontal to the ground and you are going to stack. I am sure I recall later games letting you lean and correct so you can land flat. That's a minor gripe, because it only happens when you've stuffed up, but it's frustrating because as soon as you do it you know it's going to be bad. Finally, it is a little glitchtastic sometimes. You are prone to ragdolling into the fourth dimension, which can happen when you are just trying to grind something or wall ride and don't hit it quite right. It's like you hit a pebble or something and then fly 5 stories into the air. Something is not quite right with the physics of that. Apart from that the game is pretty stable. It's not like it crashes but its a glitch. Still a fun game 20 years later

Posted: March 12, 2015
												I've been a big fan of the tony hawks games for a long time. Thps1 and Thps2 on the PS1 gave me a lot of single player fun. The games after that gave me many hours of multiplayer fun. While i can appreciate this game for what its trying to be i just can't get into it like many of the later games. - Did i enjoy thps1 and 2? yes - Do i feel nostalgic about those games and gameplay? yes- Do i want to relive that level of gameplay and control NO. The thing about this game is that really doesn't settle with me is the controls, it really does feel like those early thps games which is obviously what they were aiming for but i feel like they really missed their peak with this remake. This should have been a game celebrating much more than just the original but celebrating the evolution of the series. Pros- Some different gameplay modes, projectives, hawkman, big head mode etc are all nice additions- Enough hours of gameplay to be something- looks great, how i would imagine the levels would look in modern day graphics- Soundtrack is nice has some of the original tracks and a few others- A great selection of levels from across the seriesCons- I miss graffiti, peds with goals, the usual game modes- no multiplayer- revert is a dlc? what the hell are you trying to be old thps style or not make up your mind- no create a skater/park/trick etc- its just lacking that neversoft touchOk so i will recommend this game but here are my recommendations..- If you like the original thps games you will like this.- If you haven't really played much thps games you will most likely get used to the gameplay and mostly enjoy this.- If you are someone who spent hours and hours of time playing thps3/thps4/thug/thug2 online or offline you will probably feel like me a little dissapointed but may enjoy it if you put in more than a few hours and get used to its quirks.

												Fun bit of reminiscing for those old enough to remember this on PS1 & PC back in the last century. Do not purchase this unless you have a game controller. The XBOX 360 controller works well. It is pretty much unplayable on keyboard unless you are a masochist, really, don't even try.So, I realise that with remakes there are fanatical cannon dorks who want you to stay true to the original, but really, this is not one of those situations. Leaving out the tranny revert was a mistake; landing on the ramp transition and doing a revert into a manual is a feature from later games that this really should have. Only the 3 levels in the DLC pack apparently have that. The other major linking trick missing is the wall plant. Wall rides are there, great, but the wall plant lets you fly head on at a wall, pause momentarily and then effectively bounce off and head back the way you came. These two tricks allow for very long high scoring runs, and should have been coded in. I mean, it's not like Devs had to create the game from scratch right ;) (Yes I am downplaying the work involved in updating a game's textures and resolution to HD, but think about the level design and and the other stuff they didn't need to do).  There is also no way out of a bad ramp exit. If you fly off the side of the ramp, your body is effectively horizontal to the ground and you are going to stack. I am sure I recall later games letting you lean and correct so you can land flat. That's a minor gripe, because it only happens when you've stuffed up, but it's frustrating because as soon as you do it you know it's going to be bad. Finally, it is a little glitchtastic sometimes. You are prone to ragdolling into the fourth dimension, which can happen when you are just trying to grind something or wall ride and don't hit it quite right. It's like you hit a pebble or something and then fly 5 stories into the air. Something is not quite right with the physics of that. Apart from that the game is pretty stable. It's not like it crashes but its a glitch. Still a fun game 20 years later

Posted: February 19, 2015
												I loved it, this was THPS But at it's best I didn't find any bugs or glitches, the only time I fell down or got stuck was when I messed up a landing, this game is by far the most realistic skateboarding game to date!!! I remember the ps1 controls for this game and they are right on the money for the xbox 360 controller for the pc, X=Square, Y = Triangle, B= circle, A=X, right trigger= switch/ spin, left trigger=fakey/spin...I have no idea what people are talking about "they messed up the controls". I used to skate years ago and the physics on this game felt real and if you mess up you are punished accordingly, after about 20-30 minutes of getting used to the physics that just beat the pants out of all other skateboarding games I was back to hitting all the high scores and busting out insane combo's whilst having an even better time than I had in any of it's predecessors. Best purchase I have made in years, when I said  very realistic I meant that in gfx and physics aswell as how it actually feels when you take off of a ramp and line up the landing the charecters movement are almost completely flawless and in alot of cases I found the movements perfected and they left in the rediculous obsurd jumps, rail and ledges that keep it fun which is why it is still a game and not a sim although they aren't far off.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												After hearing many negative things about this game, I was finally able to try it for myself, and I must say it is a mediocre game at best. It is very shallow, even compared to the source matieral. I want to go into detail and list why I do not recommend this game as a Tony Hawk veteran, and not based on blind hatred.First, A few pros:1) Game looks great. It gives what it sells itself on.2) Other gamemodes are intresting enough to replay levels. They may be bland or uninspired, but it's something to do, about all you'd expect from side modes.3) Stable(ish) PC port4) Much of the old soundtrack was brought back, with some new school tunes thrown in as well.5) Very cheap, especially on sale.Now, why I gave this game a negative review.My Personal Gripes:1) Even though it includes levels from both THPS1 and THPS2, the fact that only a few from each were included was a huge letdown. The lack of New York, Philly, and even School 1, very good maps, were axed in favour of levels like Hangar, and yet ANOTHER DHJ. 2) Goal variety and creativity was very limited. In absensce of Interesting goals or ideas, almost every extra goal made for THPS1 levels were "Collect 5 ___". We already have Skate letters and the original goals, making them seem extremley redundant and halting any kind of flow you could get in the first place when collecting goals.   And let's talk about the "Projectives". On the first level, it shows some promise as a fun gamemode, more challenge and more goals for levels is something I can get down with, If not every level HAD THE EXACT SAME GOALS. Like seriously?! Combo and score I can understand, but who the ♥♥♥♥ wanted to boneless over a bum in EVERY level?3)  While I understand it is a remake and is supposed to follow the source matieral, they copied almost everything bad about previous games as well. Special manuals being on grabs, the old school special system, and Big Drops are all things we could have lived without.4) Zero Create a Modes. No Parks, No Skaters, nothing.5) On the topic of skaters, this game's cast is lackluster. This is more of a personal complaint than an objective view, but  so many skaters from the original are missing. If they got Steve and Rodney's old asses back, Why not Jamie, Bob, or anyone else? 6)  The complete lack of competitions is a little offputing. I could have lived without them, but giving goals to competition maps that weren't based around regular goals feels extremley awkward. But then again, with this game's 7 non DLC maps, doubt they could fit it anyways. And that was just my personal list, here's why I think the game is Mechanically badPure Mechanical Failures:1) Manuals are far too sensitive. 50% of the time after a bail, you start in a manual because of how sensitive the controls are. They worked fine in previous games, what happened here?2) Game is WAYYY too floaty. It's constantly enabled moon gravity, hell, With max air and hang time you go FARTHER than you would with moon gravity. It makes the game feel super awkward and inconsistant. 3) Combos drop super easy in this game. Whether it be manuals, reverts, or even grinds sometimes, you are at the games mercy of whether or not you keep your combo going. Extremley frustrating.4) Hitboxes are insanley inconcistent. It's either a mile wide or a pixel small. This has always been a problem in the franchise, but it's a glaring issue here with the altered physics. I should not have to do a trick over a gap 5 times before it counts.5)  The engine in general. It handles almost nothing like older tony games, which is ok, change was expected, but this engine gives you little to no control of your movement. It feels loose and sloppy, If you are a veteran Tony Hawk fan, only pick up this game on sale if you're curious enough. It is not worth the money or your time. I gave this game a legitimate chance and tried to turn the other cheek, but I couldn't. Avoid this game if you're looking for a genuine tony experience.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												I rarely write reviews for games, THPSHD is not as bad as the negative reviews pose it to be. If you're a true fan you'll accept that this is an old school game remastered to life. Yes it has it's faults but i've been playing 23 hours on record and still come back for more. It's obviously not a 24/7 kind of game, but just a sit back and relax type of (arcade) as i would call it. I don't own any consoles anymore as i've travelled abroad. I've been craving a tony hawk game for a while and decided regardless of the negative reviews i'll still get it. I don't regret 1 penny. The nostalgic feel with the remastered graphics blows the game out of the water. Don't forget this game came out a loooong time ago obviously you can't compare it to anything new.In conclusion. don't refrain from the negative reviews. This is not a paid advertisment, i'm just a skater gamer that always loved the Tony Hawk games, and would recommend this game to any true skater fan.

Posted: April 15, 2016
												Buy this game, especially if it's on sale. Buy it to support the concept of Tony Hawk's games on PC, buy it for a couple hours of quick fun, buy it for some nostalgic bliss. DO NOT buy it if you're hoping for a next gen installment of THPS. The graphics are quite good, actually, but the controls are impossible to master, and theres a lot of stuff that it is missing. Namly, wall/sticker slaps. It's very difficult to keep a beast combo going without wall slaps. Moreover, there doesn't appear to be spine transfers, but in their place there is an unreliable action notice when you transfer. You can't get off your board, but that's more of a luxury anyways. When I was very little, I played THPS 3, but I really grew up playing the Underground games, but still, I'm certain this game is using an old engine, from one of the first couple games.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												I loved it, this was THPS But at it's best I didn't find any bugs or glitches, the only time I fell down or got stuck was when I messed up a landing, this game is by far the most realistic skateboarding game to date!!! I remember the ps1 controls for this game and they are right on the money for the xbox 360 controller for the pc, X=Square, Y = Triangle, B= circle, A=X, right trigger= switch/ spin, left trigger=fakey/spin...I have no idea what people are talking about "they messed up the controls". I used to skate years ago and the physics on this game felt real and if you mess up you are punished accordingly, after about 20-30 minutes of getting used to the physics that just beat the pants out of all other skateboarding games I was back to hitting all the high scores and busting out insane combo's whilst having an even better time than I had in any of it's predecessors. Best purchase I have made in years, when I said  very realistic I meant that in gfx and physics aswell as how it actually feels when you take off of a ramp and line up the landing the charecters movement are almost completely flawless and in alot of cases I found the movements perfected and they left in the rediculous obsurd jumps, rail and ledges that keep it fun which is why it is still a game and not a sim although they aren't far off.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												6/10This game is alright, it feels like a mashup of THPS 1-3 with some new skaters. The game itself is visually appealing, but I am dissapointed that the only option in the graphics menu is the ability to alter the resolution, this is a little shabby for a modern PC port. The selection of levels is OK, although personally I feel they could have added a few more to the mix, such as downtown minneapolis from THPS1, Skate street from THPS2. My only problem with the levels is that some of them haven't been adapted to the new game engine, meaning that certain gaps and goals are now more difficult to achieve than in the original games, one of the main examples of this is the venice beach level in which certain gaps and goals have had their difficulty unneccessarily increased, this down to the fact that your skater moves slower than in the classic games. The new engine is nice and it feels like they tried to emulate the THPS3 engine but with more realistic movement, however the game will sometimes throw you off your board even if you don't bail, this can be annoying when trying to get a high score. I'm not too bothered about the lack of multiplayer but local multiplayer/splitscreen would have been an asset here. I'm also dissapointed that you can't dismount your board in order to look around a level in order to find certain goals like in the THUG games. In conclusion it has potential but it feels rushed, it feels like they spent more time porting the levels and making all the movements seem hyper realistic that they forgot to see whether or not their game actually worked properly.tl;dr, buy this if its on sale like I did, otherwise stick to the older games as THUG, THUG-2 and THAW all feature updated versions of the classic levels

Posted: December 5, 2015
												(16.6 hours of time spent before I reviewed it)This game gets a lot of negative reviews, but since I haven’t played any of the old THPS or any TH games, I still enjoy it.When you start the game, you can select from several different skaters who weren’t in the older games like Tony Hawk’s son Riley Hawk. Each character has their own special ability, for instance Rodney Mullen is great at doing manuals in the game while other characters may not be as good. The levels to the game are taken from THPS and it’s sequel THPS2, ranging from a hangar to a mall. The music can get quiet annoying and repetitive throughout the levels.When you are playing through the objective mode, the levels can seem monotonous since all your doing is tricks and collecting things. On some stages its really fun to do the objectives but on others, not so much. If you get tired of doing the same old objectives, you can take a break in Free Skate mode. I actually find that mode to be somewhat relaxing. There are a few other modes like one where you have to follow a certain path doing a certain kind of trick.There is one DLC pack that adds some more mechanics, stages, and characters from THPS3.Overall, I like the game. It does have its issues like the repetitiveness, but it has plenty of redeeming qualities like fun gameplay.I rate this game a 8/10~bottlehead

Posted: November 10, 2016
												I am a long time fan of the Tony Hawk GamesI have played starting from 2 on PSOne all the way through Project 8 (Not counting the Ride Games and 5).I find this on sale on Humble and I wonder "How did I miss this one?" So I bought it without thinking, played and waited with halted breath as the first level loaded. And I almost instantly hated it.For a start, the tight controls of the original are gone. It is very floaty, especcially in the air. Some of the tricks look exactly the same, The indy and the melon have the same animations. The same animations for a completley different trick. You can't change the songs mid-playthrough like you could in the originals, or even out of the game. And remember how every time you grind mid-trick you fall apart completley? no? Because That's new and a pain to deal with when chaining jump tricks with grinding. The new physics engine definetly doesn't help here, I never played 5 but it looks like the physics are the same as the ones from Tony Hawk 5, though less buggy. And There's no created characters. The funny part is we already have a decent remake for Tony Hawk 2, it's called Tony Hawk Pro Skater 2x on the xbox. And it controls fine, it looks better, and the controls are tightIf you want a true remake to the original games, go play that if you have an xbox.One good thing is the original music is here, I figured they'd have lost the rights to the songs by now.Overal I say this game is a dissapointment, not as much as Tony Hawk 5. But compared to the originals, this sucks.I give it a 4/10.<UPDATE>I nominated this game to an award I call, "Anger Simulator" to express how everytime I want to feel like I am actually angry. I play this game.

												It is worth it if you are a big Tony Hawk  fan, I enjoy it but would have preferred a remake for THPS3.  That was by far the best.They did add some new elements and moves that are nice, but the engine it runs on feels goofy. The music is not all the same but that is alright. They added a some new characters as well which look great. To me, it would be worth it if it was sub $5.  and I am a big fan of the classic THPS games. I did enjoy the newer ones but at project 8, it was no longer interesting.**Update**  Super glitchy and playing any of the original 3 is a better use of time.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												Well at least it's not Ride or Shred.. Gameplay is messed up, doesn't have that quick TH's feeling like THPS3 and THPS4 had. The graphics looks nice and I love the soundtrack, unfortunantly that's pretty much it. No new levels and just a few skaters (I know it's a "remake", but still). They ♥♥♥♥ed up the balance meter so good luck going for insane scores. Robomodo had an amazing opportunity to revive this series but they failed to deliver.Anyways,  I did occasionally enjoy this game and it's definitely not a horrible game. It's just not a good Tony Hawk's game. Go get THUG 2 and download the THUG PRO mod instead, because you're worth it <3
